1.brief: David, the youngest son of Jesse
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)
properly, to plump, i.e. fill up hollows; by implication, to cover (for clothing or secrecy)
a covering, i.e. clothing; also treachery or pillage
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
probably to be hot; figuratively, to conceive

2.brief: to search out (by any method, specifically in worship or prayer); by implication, to strive after
a virgin (from her privacy); sometimes (by continuation) a bride; also (figuratively) a city or state
to stand, in various relations (literal and figurative, intransitive and transitive)
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
to be familiar with; by implication, to minister to, be serviceable to, be customary
to lie down (for rest, sexual connection, decease or any other purpose)

3.brief: to search out (by any method, specifically in worship or prayer); by implication, to strive after
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
properly, a cord (as twisted), i.e. (by implication) a boundary; by extension the territory inclosed
Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity
properly, to come forth to, i.e. appear or exist; transitively, to attain, i.e. find or acquire; figuratively, to occur, meet or be present

properly, vehemence, i.e. (with or without preposition) vehemently; by implication, wholly, speedily, etc. (often with other words as an intensive or superlative; especially when repeated)
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
to be familiar with; by implication, to minister to, be serviceable to, be customary
to attend as a menial or worshipper; figuratively, to contribute to
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)

a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)

to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
a vehicle; by implication, a team; by extension, cavalry; by analogy a rider, i.e. the upper millstone
a steed (as stretched out to a vehicle, not single nor for mounting ); also (by implication) a driver (in a chariot), i.e. (collectively) cavalry
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
to run (for whatever reason, especially to rush)
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
